SENT.plain: We investigated the relationship between age and laughing and smiling in children with Angelman syndrome
Twenty-four children with Angelman syndrome were exposed to three experimentally manipulated conditions: proximity only, restricted social interaction, and social interaction
Children smiled the most in the social interaction condition and the least in the proximity only condition confirming the effect of social interaction on these behaviors
There was a decline in smiling and laughing in the oldest group (13.4-15.9 years) only in the social interaction condition
This trajectory of a decline in resource soliciting behaviors with age is consistent with predictions based on kinship theory
